settings.specialized__what_content:
Graves Disease is an autoimmune disease that causes damage to the thyroid gland and results in hyperthyroidism. While there are a number of causes of hyperthyroidism, Graves Disease is the most common cause. 

Graves Disease occurs when the immune system attacks the thyroid gland and causes it to produce too much thyroid hormone. This affects a number of functions in the body and results in a number of symptoms. Typically, Graves Disease affects and is diagnosed in people between the ages of 30 and 50 years old, and tends to be more common in women.

settings.heading: What is a thyroid gland and where is it located?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: Your thyroid is a small butterfly-shaped organ located at the bottom of your neck.

settings.heading: What is the Thyroid Gland Responsible for?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
The thyroid gland is a hormone gland and is a part of your endocrine system. It helps regulate vital functions such as metabolism, growth, and body development and can also affect heart rate, temperature, digestive function, brain development, and more. 

When you have Graves Disease your thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone which results in some bodily functions speeding up. This can result in a number of symptoms which we will discuss next.

settings.heading: What are the symptoms of Graves Disease?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
• Enlarged thyroid (known as a goiter)
  • Bulging eyes
  • Irregular heartbeat
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty sleeping or resting
  • Tremors
  • Muscle Weakness
  • Heat intolerance
  • Weight loss
  • Irritability

settings.heading: How is Graves Disease Treated?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans: If you and your doctor discover that you have Graves Disease then they may decide it's best to prescribe you certain medications or treatments to put the disease in remission. While Graves Disease is a lifelong disease, it is treatable and oftentimes it can be put into remission.

settings.heading: Can Graves Disease Cause Hair Loss?
settings.specialized__faqs_ans:
Graves Disease can cause hair loss. Since Graves Disease speeds up functions in the body, it can put stress on certain processes like hair growth. Occasionally this can cause Telogen Effluvium hair loss.

While this hair loss is typically temporary and your normal hair cycle should resume once your Graves Disease is treated, there are a few best practices you can incorporate into your hair care routine to best support your hair health and growth.
